skill.name: Frontend Accessibility
skill.description: Implement accessible user interfaces with semantic HTML, keyboard navigation, sufficient color contrast, screen reader support, ARIA attributes, and proper focus management. Use this skill when creating or editing React components (.tsx, .jsx files), when implementing forms with labels and inputs, when building interactive elements (buttons, modals, menus, dialogs), when implementing keyboard navigation, when choosing colors and ensuring contrast ratios, when adding ARIA attributes, when testing with screen readers, when implementing focus states and focus management, or when creating heading structures and page landmarks.
skill.summary: Implement accessible user interfaces with semantic HTML, keyboard navigation, sufficient color contr...
skill.author: DevanB

security_audit.summary: This is a pure guidance/prompt-based skill with no executable code. It contains only documentation and instructions for implementing accessibility features. No security risks detected.

content.value_statement: Building accessible web interfaces ensures everyone can use your applications, including users with disabilities. This skill enforces WCAG standards, proper ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, and screen reader compatibility in your React components.
actual_capabilities: Enforces WCAG 2.1 AA compliance standards in React components
Adds proper ARIA attributes and semantic HTML elements
Implements keyboard navigation and focus management
Ensures 4.5:1 color contrast ratios and visible focus indicators
Creates logical heading hierarchies and page landmarks
limitations: Only works with React components (.tsx, .jsx files)
Requires manual testing with actual screen readers
Cannot automatically fix all accessibility issues
Focuses on frontend code, not backend accessibility

use_cases.title: Build accessible React components
use_cases.description: Create buttons, forms, and interactive elements that work with screen readers and keyboard navigation

use_cases.title: Maintain accessibility standards
use_cases.description: Ensure all UI components meet WCAG guidelines with proper ARIA attributes and contrast ratios

use_cases.title: Comply with accessibility regulations
use_cases.description: Meet ADA, Section 508, and WCAG requirements to avoid legal issues and serve all users

prompt_templates.title: Make form accessible
prompt_templates.scenario: Adding labels and keyboard navigation to a contact form
prompt_templates.prompt: Make this contact form fully accessible with proper labels, ARIA attributes, and keyboard navigation

prompt_templates.title: Add ARIA to modal
prompt_templates.prompt: Add proper ARIA attributes, focus management, and keyboard controls to this modal component

prompt_templates.title: Fix color contrast
prompt_templates.prompt: Update these component colors to meet WCAG 2.1 AA contrast ratio requirements (4.5:1 minimum)

prompt_templates.title: Build accessible navigation
prompt_templates.prompt: Build an accessible navigation menu with proper ARIA landmarks, keyboard navigation, and screen reader support

output: Semantic button element with proper type attribute
Visible focus indicator with 3:1 contrast ratio
Accessible name via text content or aria-label
Keyboard activation with Enter and Space keys
Disabled state properly communicated to assistive technology
ARIA pressed state for toggle buttons

best_practices: Always include proper labels for form inputs using htmlFor and id attributes
Test components with keyboard-only navigation before shipping
Use semantic HTML elements (nav, main, button) instead of divs with ARIA
anti_patterns: Don't use divs with onClick handlers instead of proper button elements
Avoid color-only indicators without text or icon alternatives
Never remove focus outlines without providing custom focus indicators

faq.question: Which screen readers should I test with?
faq.answer: Test with NVDA (Windows), JAWS (Windows), VoiceOver (Mac/iOS), and TalkBack (Android) for comprehensive coverage

faq.question: What WCAG level should I target?
faq.answer: Aim for WCAG 2.1 Level AA compliance as the minimum standard for most applications

faq.question: How do I check color contrast ratios?
faq.answer: Use tools like WebAIM's contrast checker or browser extensions to verify 4.5:1 minimum contrast

faq.question: Can this skill fix existing accessibility issues?
faq.answer: It guides you to fix issues but cannot automatically refactor existing code - you'll need to implement the suggestions

faq.question: Does this work with other frameworks?
faq.answer: Currently optimized for React - principles apply elsewhere but examples are React-specific

faq.question: How do I handle complex interactive widgets?
faq.answer: Follow ARIA authoring practices patterns and test thoroughly with keyboard and screen readers
